questions.question:
Question 1: Your worried friend calls you for advice after attending a family function. He informs you that 
his aunt, who also travelled to the function in the same car, tested positive for COVID-19. 
What is your advice for your friend?
questions.explanation:
Home quarantine for 14 days is advised when a person comes in contact with a COVID-19 positive 
patient. The home quarantined person: • Should stay in a well ventilated single room and stay away from high-risk individuals • Should not attend any religious or social gatherings • Must wash hands often • Must change mask every 6-8 hrs • Their surroundings must be disinfected with 1% sodium hypochlorite solution In case the person being quarantined becomes symptomatic, all his contacts should be home 
quarantined for 14 days and followed up for another 14 days or till the report turns out negative 
on lab testing. 1552 
Sold by @itachibot Isolation is the separation and restriction of movements or activities of persons who are sick, to 
prevent the transmission of disease. Quarantine is the separation and restriction of movements or 
activities of persons who are not ill but are believed to have been exposed to infection, for the 
purpose of preventing transmission of diseases.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 50-year-old man recovering from COVID-19 presents as follows. His medical and personal 
histories are insignificant with no exposure to cold. What would you suspect?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of COVID toes. The image shows pernio-like lesions 
caused due to COVID-19. Pernio / chilblains are skin lesions on the acral surfaces of the body characterised by the 
development of erythematous-violaceous or purpuric macules. They may be accompanied by 
edema and pruritus. It is usually due to cold exposure or underlying hematological disorders but has also been 
reported in patients with COVID-19 disease. The underlying mechanism is thought to be an 
inflammatory process. The lesions appear late (postviral phase) with the patients exhibiting 
positive IgM/ IgG antibodies for SARS-CoV-2 and negative RT-PCR. However, pernio like lesions 
can also be seen in early stages of the disease when the patients are still infective. There are no treatment guidelines but high-potency topical corticosteroids may be helpful if the 
lesions are causing discomfort. Other cutaneous manifestations include exanthematous rash, 
livedo reticularis, urticaria, MIS-C etc.

questions.question: Question 3: While donning a set of PPE, what is the order that you will follow?
questions.explanation:
The correct sequence of donning a PPE is first pair of gloves  coverall  Shoe cover  N-95 
mask. Preparation for donning the PPE: • To be performed only in the designated area • The health care worker must be prepared for the shift duty by • Taking a meal • Using the washroom • Drinking water prior to entering the donning area • Remove all accessories, jewelry • Change into clean hospital scrubs and closed washable footwear • Perform hand hygiene with soap and water Steps of donning/putting on the PPE: • Hand hygiene • Wear the first pair of gloves • Sterile or unsterile 1553 
Sold by @itachibot • Make sure the cuff of the gloves goes as far as possible • Examine and wear coverall • Examine the coverall for any damage • Start by wearing the leg sleeves and then the arm sleeves • Zip up and cover the zip with the flap attached • Wear shoe cover • Sit on the clean chair and wear shoe cover • Pull them up till your calves • Wear N-95 mask and wear hood • Hold the mask like a cup in the hand with both the straps hanging out in the front • Place the mask on the face, pull and wear the lower strap first placing it below the ears • Then pull and wear the upper strap placing above the ears • The air leakage should be minimum around the mask when forcibly exhaling • Wear the hood covering the forehead and the cheeks • Wear face shield/eye goggles over the hood and ensure the fit • Wear the second pair of gloves - pull the gloves to cover the sleeve cuff and forearm as much as 
possible

questions.question: Question 4: While doffing, what is the first component of the PPE that you would remove?
questions.explanation:
The component of the PPE kit to be removed first is the shoe covers. Preparation for doffing the PPE: • To be performed only in the designated area • Check for any leak or soiling • Doffing room should have two chairs, dirty and clean • All the PPE must be discarded in the red bin • Hand hygiene must be performed after every step Steps of doffing the PPE: • Engage the observer and ask him to check the PPE - observer should check for any leak, tear, or 
contamination of PPE. If contaminated, then it should be disinfected with alcohol-based wipes. • Disinfect the gloves • Remove and discard shoe covers • Sit on the dirty chair with legs apart • Remove the shoe covers by slowly pulling the outer surface starting from the top and then pull 
from the toes end. Discard them 1554 
Sold by @itachibot • Disinfect and remove outer pair of gloves • While removing the outer gloves, inner gloves should not be torn or contaminated • Pinch the first glove on the outer surface at the wrist and pull it inside out • Hold this glove in the other hand like a ball • Slide the thumb inside the other glove and remove inside out balling around the previous glove, 
making it into a single bag. Then discard it. • Disinfect inner gloves • Remove face shield/eye goggle - loosen the screw and remove the face shield by holding it from 
the back handle. Discard it. • Disinfect inner gloves again • Remove hood and coverall • Slide back the hood by holding it from the top • Separate the zip flap and unzip the coverall suit • Holding the suit at the arms, slide it off the shoulder slightly, then pull the suit from the side of 
the waist • Roll the arms out one by one • By touching the inner surface of the suit carefully roll out each leg. Discard it • Disinfect and remove inner gloves as previously described • Perform hand hygiene and wear a new pair of gloves • Remove and discard N-95 mask • Do not touch the exposed surface of the mask • Stoop forward and first remove the lower strap • Then pull out the upper strap and remove the mask • Disinfect gloves • Sit on the clean chair and disinfect shoes using alcohol wipes • Disinfect and remove gloves • Perform hand hygiene • Wipe the shoes on sodium hypochlorite soaked doormat at exit • Exit the doffing area and take a shower

questions.question:
Question 5: You are a medical officer at the designated COVID hospital in your city and are required to 
don PPE every day at work. Which area of the PPE should you not touch while doffing?
questions.explanation:
The front of the face shield is considered to be a contaminated area of the personal protective 
equipment (PPE). Hence, it should not be touched while doffing. The areas that are considered clean are the parts that will be touched while removing a PPE: 1555 
Sold by @itachibot • Inside the gloves • Inside and back of the gown including the ties • Ties or earpieces of the mask, goggles, and face shields The areas that are considered contaminated are: • Outside front and sleeves of the isolation gown • Front of goggles, mask, respirator, and face shield • Outside of the gloves

questions.question: Question 6: After your COVID ICU shift, where would you dispose your face shield?
questions.explanation: The face shield used by a healthcare worker during COVID-19 pandemic is disposed in the red bin.

questions.question: Question 7: What is recommended for cleaning and disinfecting a healthcare facility against COVID-19?
questions.explanation:
1% sodium hypochlorite is recommended for cleaning and disinfection against COVID-19. The sodium hypochlorite solution should be prepared fresh. Leaving the solution for a contact 
time of at least 10 minutes is recommended. Note: Alcohol (e.g. isopropyl 70% or ethyl alcohol 70%) can be used to wipe down surfaces where 
the use of bleach is not suitable, e.g. metals.

Question 9: Four days after being extubated, an elderly diabetic man with COVID-19 developed 
rhinosinusitis. The tissue obtained from the sinuses showed the following. The physician 
wanted to start the patient on amphotericin B. However, it was not available. Which other 
drug can be given to this patient? 1549 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mucormycosis. Intravenous administration of 
amphotericin B is the first line treatment. Other drugs which are approved for its management 
include isavuconazole and posaconazole. Surgical debridement is the last line management. Immunocompromised states are important risk factors including diabetes mellitus 
and glucocorticoid treatment as well as patients on ventilation. 1557 
Sold by @itachibot Diagnosis can be made by culturing the organisms from sterile sites like needle aspirate, pleural 
fluid, or a tissue biopsy specimen. The biopsy is most sensitive. It reveals characteristic wide, 
thick-walled, ribbon-like, aseptate hyphal elements that branch at right angles. It can present as: • Rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis - (most common) the initial symptoms are nonspecific and 
include eye or facial pain and facial numbness followed by the onset of conjunctival suffusion and 
blurry vision. If untreated it can spread from the sinuses to the orbit, and then to the frontal lobe. • Pulmonary mucormycosis - (second most common) • Cutaneous mucormycosis - usually results after trauma • Gastrointestinal mucormycosis - primarily occurs in premature neonates who have disseminated 
disease or necrotizing enterocolitis • Disseminated mucormycosis

questions.question:
Question 10: A young girl, who recently recovered from COVID-19, presents with fever, abdominal pain 
and rashes for 4 days. On examination, strawberry tongue is observed and cervical nodes are 
found to be enlarged bilaterally. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This is a case of multisystem inflammatory syndrome in children (MIS-C), associated with 
COVID-19 infection. Diagnostic criteria for MIS-C: Children and adolescents 0–18 years of age with fever 3 days AND two of these: • Rash or bilateral non-purulent conjunctivitis or mucocutaneous inflammation signs 
(palmoplantar erythema, lip hyperemia, periorbital erythema and edema, strawberry tongue, and 
malar erythema) • Hypotension or shock. • Features of myocardial dysfunction, pericarditis, valvulitis, or coronary abnormalities (including 
ECHO findings or elevated Troponin/NT-proBNP) • Evidence of coagulopathy (PT, PTT, elevated D-Dimers) • Acute gastrointestinal problems (diarrhoea, vomiting, or abdominal pain) AND Elevated ESR(>40 mm), C-reactive protein (>5 mg/L), or procalcitonin. AND No other obvious microbial cause of inflammation including bacterial sepsis, staphylococcal or 
streptococcal shock syndromes. AND Evidence of COVID-19 (RT-PCR, antigen test, or serology positive), or likely contact with patients 
with COVID-19. Types of MIS-C: 1558 
Sold by @itachibot • MIS-C with shock/multi-organ dysfunction • Kawasaki phenotype • MIS-C without shock MIS-C is treated with IV methylprednisolone. The dose can be increased in patients with shock. If 
the condition does not improve for 48-72 hours, specialists can be consulted for the addition of 
biologicals to the treatment regimen.

questions.question: Question 11: Which gene increases the risk of collapsing glomerulopathy in COVID-19 patients?
questions.explanation:
APOL1 gene increases the risk of collapsing nephropathy in patients infected with COVID-19. Glomerular lesions are reported in a minority of COVID-19 patients. They are associated with 
collapsing focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) and are called COVID-associated 
nephropathy (COVAN). Such patients present with nephrotic-range proteinuria and acute kidney 
injury (AKI). It specifically affects individuals of African ancestry who are carriers of this gene 
variant. Thrombotic microangiopathy is another uncommon finding among these patients. Histopathology 
is similar to those seen in other forms of collapsing glomerulopathy. But, tubulointerstitial lesions 
including microcystic tubular dilatation and tubular injury are typically associated with APOL1- 
related disease.

questions.question: Question 13: In which of the following patients, would you administer Covidshield vaccination?
questions.explanation:
The 51-year-old man should receive COVID-19 vaccination at least 3 months after hematopoietic 
cell transplantation (and not 5 weeks) to maximize vaccine efficacy. Graft-versus-host disease and immunosuppressive regimens like systemic corticosteroids can 
blunt the immune responses to vaccination. Delay of vaccination until immunosuppressive 
therapy is reduced can be considered. Consider additional risk factors linked to adverse COVID-19 complications including, but not 
limited to: • Patients with advanced age (eg, 65 years of age) • Patients with comorbidities (eg, chronic pulmonary, cardiovascular, or renal disease) • Social and demographic factors COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized over other vaccines. A gap of 14 days is recommended 
between COVID-19 vaccines and any other vaccine. If COVID vaccine has been given first, then TT vaccine can be given on the same day. If TT 
vaccine have been given first, then wait for 14 days to give COVID vaccine.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 24-year-old boy who had SARS CoV-2 infection 3 months back came with complaints of 
fatigue and shortness of breath for 3 days. The minimum duration of these symptoms to 
define it as post-Covid-19 condition according to WHO is
questions.explanation:
The minimum duration of symptoms such as fatigue, shortness of breath to define it as post 
Covid-19 condition according to WHO is 2 months. WHO clinical case definition of post Covid-19 - Post Covid-19 condition occurs in individuals with 
a history of probable or confirmed SARS CoV-2 infection, usually 3 months from the onset of 
Covid-19, with symptoms that last for at least 2 months and cannot be explained by an alternative 
diagnosis. Common symptoms include • Fatigue • Shortness of breath • Cognitive dysfunction. 1560 
Sold by @itachibot
